oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Discussion - Hitmaker's Workshop - RCA Studio B - 2007-03-10
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Discussion on the importance of RCA Studio B with professionals that worked there from the Ford Theater at the Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum on March 10, 2007.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Harold Bradley; Jerry Bradley; Jim Ed Brown; Bill Harris;
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:tableOfContents: Moderated by John Rumble. Includes questions from the audience. Opening comments by Ali Tonn. Subjects include; (03:25) Plays recording of Don Gibson's recording of Oh Lonesome Me / (05:54) Introduction to Studio B and introduction of panelists by John Rumble / (12:55) Harold Bradley on why he and his brother Owen decided on build a studio and locate in the Music Row area / (15:58) Jerry Bradley comments on real estate brokers comments about the Music Row area / (17:14) Harold talks about RCA committing to opening a studio in Nashville shortly after he and Owen opened their studio (16:10) / (19:15) The ease of recording at Studio B / (19:50) Why RCA didn't just use the Bradley studio instead of opening their own / (20:20) Jim Ed Brown talks about the differences between the TRAFCO studios and RCA Nashville studio / (21:20) Harold talks about Brown Brothers studio and Steve Sholes starting to use Chet Atkins / (22:20) Jerry Bradley talks about the sound of RCA studio Nashville /

(23:55) Steve Sholes signing Elvis Presley to the RCA record label and him having the clout to open a studio in Nashville / (26:10) Jim Ed Brown talks about his and the Browns career and the recording of The Three Bells / (32:02) Jim Ed talks about preferring to record on one microphone / (33:28) Jim Ed talks about Chet Atkins and engineer Bill Porter's contributions / (35:50) Jim Ed and Harold talk about the Anita Kerr Singers / (36:52) Jim Ed talks about mono mix downs and record production techniques / (38:55) Jim Ed talks about hearing and recording the song Pop A Top / (42:19) Plays recording of Jim Ed Brown's Pop A Top / (43:46) Harold talks about Roy Orbison working at RCA Studio and recording Only The Lonely / (45:00) Harold talks about and plays his guitar part on Orbison's Running Scared / (46:37) Plays recording of Orbison's Running Scared / (48:25) Harold talks about recording Indescribably Blue with Elvis Presley /
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:subject: Bradley, Jerry; Harris, Bill; Country Music Hall of Fame & Museum (Nashville, Tenn.); Bradley, Harold (Guitarist); Brown, Jim Ed, 1934-2015;
